question: 1) Which statements best describe how MNW differs from a WEL boundary? (Mark ALL correct answers)
success: ✅ Correct. MNW allows dynamic head computation; WEL is a fixed-flux condition.
error: ❌ WEL fixes Q, while MNW dynamically links Q and h based on resistance.

question: 2) In this plot 2, what is true about the cell head $h_{Cell}$? (Mark ALL correct answers)
success: ✅ Correct. In Plot 2, $h_{Cell}$ is fixed and used as a reference for Δh.
error: ❌ $h_{Cell}$ is fixed — only $h_{well}$ and Q change depending on mode.

question: 3) What happens if the exponent $P$ in the nonlinear CWC is increased? (Mark ALL correct answers)
success: ✅ Exactly. Higher P makes the system more nonlinear and amplifies drawdown.
error: ❌ Increasing P does not linearize or reduce resistance — quite the opposite.

question: 4) In which way does MNW behavior resemble a RIV boundary? (Mark ALL correct answers)
success: ✅ Correct. MNW and RIV both compute Q from head differences — though MNW adds nonlinearity.
error: ❌ RIV is linear; MNW can simulate nonlinear response with B and P.

question: 5) What happens when $A = 0$, $B = 0$, and only nonlinear resistance remains? (Mark ALL correct answers)
success: ✅ Yes. Removing A and B makes the curve purely nonlinear, dominated by C and P.
error: ❌ A = 0 is valid — flow is still simulated, just with nonlinear control only.

question: 6) Which conditions cause MNW to behave most like a constant-head (DRN) boundary? (Mark ALL correct answers)
success: ✅ Correct. DRN-like behavior appears in MNW when losses are linear and $h_{well}$ is the input.
error: ❌ Nonlinear turbulence and varying aquifer head move the MNW away from DRN behavior.
